div1.p: Hench requests newspaper information on William H. Dean.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Librarian, Main Public Library, Detroit, Michigan, August 26, 1940
div1.opener:
August 26, 1940
Librarian,
Main Public Library
Detroit, Michigan
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I have been asked to prepare an address on the conquest of
yellow fever, to be given on the occasion of the dedication of the Lazear Memorial,
October 26. The address will later be published in an extended form, in a medical
historical journal. I would appreciate greatly your help regarding two points:

Major Walter Reed, the head of the U.S. Army Board in Cuba,
which discovered the cause of yellow fever, and of which Lazear was a member,
decided that human experiments were necessary. Dr. Carroll, a member of the board,
was the first to develop experimental yellow fever. The second was an army private,
William H. Dean, who later, I understand, lived and died in Detroit, dying on
May 3, 1928. Do you have newspapers of that day or the next day, giving any
information about his life and death, possibly also a photograph? Would it be
possible for me to get a phostatic copy of this material.

I understand that some bridge in Detroit was named after him--
the Dean Bridge. I have asked a physician friend of mine, who lives in Detroit,
but he does not know of any such bridge. Do you know of any such bridge and could
you tell me exactly where it is located in Detroit?

I appreciate whatever help you can give me in this, very
greatly indeed.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
